title: A Wheelchair User Goes to Space for the First Time
summary: A German engineer named Michaela Benthaus became the first person in a wheelchair to go to space. She flew on a rocket from Texas with five other people. Michaela had a bike accident seven years ago and uses a wheelchair, but she left it behind to float in space. The rocket, called New Shepard, was made by a company called Blue Origin. It flew over 65 miles high for about 10 minutes. The company made small changes to help Michaela, like adding a board to move into her seat. After landing, she got back to her wheelchair right away. Michaela was very happy and said it was a cool experience. This shows that more people, including those with disabilities, can dream of going to space.

background_read: Space is a big place above Earth where astronauts go. Rockets are special vehicles that can fly people to space. Some people use wheelchairs to move if they cannot walk. Companies like Blue Origin are making space travel easier for everyone, including people with disabilities. This story is about a brave engineer who showed that dreams can come true.
Article_Structure: WHO: Michaela Benthaus, a German engineer who uses a wheelchair
WHAT: She became the first wheelchair user to go to space on a rocket
WHERE: The rocket launched from West Texas, USA
WHY: To show that space travel can be accessible to more people, including those with disabilities

perspectives.description: This event highlights efforts to make space travel possible for people with disabilities, promoting equality and inspiration.
